Award.AwardTitle: Planning Visit to China: Think Green - Energy, Education, Environmental Initiatives; Nanjing, China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a planning visit to China by a group of US faculty. Professors Nada Assaf-Anid of New York Institute of Technology (NYIT) and Alan Mickelson (U Colorado-Boulder) together with a cohort of scientists and engineers from NYIT and other institutions will visit with faculty at Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications (NUPT). The visit will take place in conjunction with the two-day forum, Think Green: Energy, Education,
Environmental Initiatives, that will be held April 8 ? 9, 2010, as a collaborative and multi-disciplinary effort between NYIT and NUPT, in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. The goal of the visit is to undertake onsite discussions about research collaborations between NYIT?s School of Engineering and Computing Sciences, the University of Colorado?s Mortenson Center in Engineering for Developing Communities and NUPT, building on the three institutions? combined expertise in information and communication systems, tele-health, tele-education, embedded-systems technologies. Discussions will revolve around the development of independent, sustainable power-generation systems, such as pico- and micro-hydro or solar devices, wind and hybrid power systems, as well as smart gridding and smart networks with the development of environmental monitoring/control technologies.

The technical impact of this collaboration is likely to benefit engineering and computing research in all three institutions. Progress on new energy systems will yield global benefits. The collaboration will also enhance scientific cooperation between Chinese and US faculty and provide students from both nations with opportunities for international research experience.

Project Outcomes Report for Award 1031961

 

Think Green: Energy, Education, Environmental Initiatives

 

Project Objectives and Expected Outcomes:

 

The proposed planning visit will take place in conjunction with a two-day forum that will be held April 8 – 9, 2010, as a collaborative effort between New York Institute of Technology (NYIT) and Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications (NUPT), in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China.  The forum is supported by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) and other academic and private entities and some of its participants from NYIT-NY (Dr. Nada Assaf-Anid), the University of Colorado-Boulder (Dr. Alan Mickelson), and NYIT-NUPT (Drs. George Kostopoulos and Douglas Van Wieren) will be actively engaged in the planning visit. 

 

The overarching goal of the planning visit is to initiate onsite discussions about research collaborations between NYIT’s School of Engineering and Computing Sciences and its Center for Global Health, NUPT, and the University of Colorado’s Mortenson Center in Engineering for Developing Communities, building on the three institutions’ combined expertise and areas of overlap in teaching and research, mainly in computer science and engineering (electrical, energy, environmental), sustainability, and public health.  Specific objectives and expected outcomes are listed below:

 

Objective 1: Develop a detailed strategic plan and framework for research collaboration between three institutions (NYIT-NUPT-CU Boulder).

 

Outcomes under objective 1:

Outcome 1.1. Review research capacity of all three institutions in the areas of interest.

Outcome 1.2. Identify limitations of existing resources. Conduct Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats (SWOT) analysis. Define the problems that need to be addressed.


Outcome 1.3. Develop time line, tasks, planning, and needed resources for proposed collaborative work.

 

Objective 2: Develop a detailed strategic plan and framework for collaboration in education between the three institutions. The plan will involve a joint service learning course that will be used as a vehicle to initiate the collaboration.

 

Outcomes under objective 2:

 

Outcome 2.1. Review capacity of all three institutions in education and service/outreach that will engage students in the areas of interest.

Outcome 2.2. Identify limitations of existing resources. Develop SWOT analysis. Lay special weight on distance learning (including tele-conferencing and tele-teaching) facilities and capabilities.

Outcome 2.3. Develop time line, tasks, planning, and needed resources for proposed collaborative work including a tentative course outline for the service learning course.

 

Objective 3: Launch the first chapter of EWB-China at NUPT and integrate it into NUPT's curricular structure through service learning.


Outcomes under objective 3:

Outcome 3.1. Create EWB-China's structures and operation components.


Outcome 3.2. Develop a framework integrating EWB-China activities into the education, R&D and service learning mission at NUPT.


Outcome 3.3. Develop a mechanism for joint efforts involving the NYIT and CU Boulder chapters ...
